availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: James Shipp Phelps (Christian County, Kentucky, farmer and merchant, and Louisville, Kentucky, tobacconist.)

body.p: Christian County, Kentucky, farmer and merchant, and Louisville, Kentucky, tobacconist. Christian County, Kentucky, native. Son of John Phelps and Katharine Shipp Phelps. Married to Mary Jane Glass Phelps in Christian County, Kentucky, on July 25, 1849. Father of John H. Phelps, James C. Phelps, Zack Phelps, and Laban Phelps. Resident of Christian County, Kentucky, in 1850. Household owned nineteen enslaved persons in Christian County in 1850. Merchant in partnership with Joseph K. Grant in Christian County in 1853. Farmer and merchant in Christian County in 1860. Employed F. Bashler as a gardener in Christian County in 1860. Owned fourteen enslaved persons in Christian County in 1860. Manager of the Western Lunatic Asylum in Christian County from February 1861 to 1862. Resident of Louisville in 1862. Tobacconist in the firm of Phelps, Caldwell & Company in Louisville from 1862 to 1867.

ab.bibl:

Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Christian County, District 1.

"James Shipp Phelps Will Be Buried To-Day," The Courier-Journal (Louisville, KY), August 21, 1913, p. 7.
J. Stoddard Johnston, Memorial History of Louisville: From Its First Settlement to the Year 1896, vol. I (Chicago: American Biographical Publishing Co., 1896), 482-3.
